items.title: Green Day to Resume Touring
items.author: By Allan Kozinn
items.abstract: Green Day has announced that it will begin touring again in March.

items.title: Pulling Carbon Dioxide Out of Thin Air
items.author: By Anne Eisenberg
items.abstract: A Canadian company plans to build a pilot plant to determine whether removing carbon dioxide directly from the atmosphere can be cost-effective.

items.title: More On a Quest for Common Ground on Climate Change
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: An animated view of the common ground that’s possible on climate change between people with different politics.

items.title: Officials Seek Energy Drink Information
items.author: By Barry Meier
items.abstract: Three Democratic members of Congress sent letters to marketers to find out more about the safety of the drinks, which have come under scrutiny by the F.D.A.

items.title: Obama’s Second-Term Options on the Environment
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: What Obama can do to cut climate risk and improve the environment in his second term.

items.title: A Green Oasis at the Heart of a Concrete Jungle
items.author: By Nicholas Gill
items.abstract: The Jardins area of São Paulo, Brazil, is popular as a residential area but also includes top-end shopping and restaurant options.

items.title: Greener Pastures
items.author: By Alan Ehrenhalt
items.abstract: Charles Montgomery melds urban design and the science of happiness in this globe-trotting exploration of city living.

items.title: Slowly, Asia’s Factories Begin to Turn Green
items.author: By Mike Ives
items.abstract: Multinationals and local suppliers are increasingly going beyond local regulations in designing factories that cut energy costs and pollute less.
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)

items.title: Journalists on the Environment Beat Look Ahead
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: Seasoned journalists covering the environment explore themes that will be in headlines this year, and some that won’t, but should be.

items.title: From Warheads to Cheap Energy
items.author: By William J. Broad
items.abstract: In all, over two decades, the program known as Megatons to Megawatts turned 20,000 Russian warheads into electricity that has illuminated one in 10 American light bulbs.
keywords: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

items.title: A Sense of Frenetic Energy in a Hardscrabble World
items.author: By Ben Ratliff
items.abstract: The Winter Jazzfest marathon marked its 11th year with performances around the city.

items.title: Green-Energy Inspiration Off the Coast of Denmark
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: Residents of islands off Maine’s coast seek to draw on the experiences of the Danish island Samso in an effort to explore alternative sources of light and heat.

items.title: Leaders in Davos Urge Quick Action to Alter the Effects of Climate Change
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Business and political leaders called on governments to set clear goals so companies are prompted to act before the problems of climate change become irreversible.

items.title: A Multiplicity of Voices in High-Energy Movement
items.author: By Siobhan Burke
items.abstract: Parsons Dance, performing at the Joyce Theater, has unveiled a world premiere by the former company member Natalie Lomonte, alongside new and old works.

items.title: A Climate Hawk Separates Energy Thought Experiments from Road Maps
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: A progressive “climate hawk” says simplified road maps for solving the climate challenge are counterproductive.

items.title: ‘The Love of Strangers,’ by Nile Green
items.author: By Anita Anand
items.abstract: A story of Iranians who studied in England in the 19th century.
keywords: The Love of Strangers: What Six Muslim Students Learned in Jane Austen's London (Book)

items.title: Dining in Thunder Bay, Where Sustainable Meets Delectable
items.author: By Robert Lillegard
items.abstract: Uptown Cut has a modern sensibility yet takes pride in the beef of Ontario.

items.title: New York Hotels Make a Green Pledge
items.author: By Shivani Vora
items.abstract: Seventeen New York City hotels have pledged to serve the environment by joining the NYC Carbon Challenge.
keywords: Waldorf Astoria New York (Manhattan, NY, Hotel)

items.title: Why Green Bay Should Have Chosen Boldness
items.author: By Gregg Easterbrook
items.abstract: The Packers, with a recent record of playing it “safe” in the playoffs, fell short again after not trying for a two-point conversion.

items.title: S.E.C. Is Criticized for Lax Enforcement of Climate Risk Disclosure
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Critics say the Securities and Exchange Commission’s oversight of disclosure of the risks of the effects of climate change has waned, costing shareholders millions.

items.title: Going Green in ’17
items.abstract: An environmental consultant writes that the cumulative effect of personal direct actions can be significant.

items.title: China Aims to Spend at Least $360 Billion on Renewable Energy by 2020
items.author: By Michael Forsythe
items.abstract: China’s announcement was a bold claim on leadership in the renewable energy industry, where Chinese companies are already among the world’s dominant players.

items.title: Where Sustainable Travel Is Headed in 2017
items.author: By Shivani Vora
items.abstract: What groups and businesses are doing to make tourism more globally aware in the coming year.

items.title: Trump May Not Like Alternative Energy, but Investors Should
items.author: By Paul Sullivan
items.abstract: With clean energy creating jobs in every state, the sector has become as much about getting returns on investments as it is about helping the environment.

items.title: At Sundance, the Theme Is Climate Change
items.author: By Brooks Barnes
items.abstract: “An Inconvenient Sequel,” a follow-up to Al Gore’s Oscar-winning film, is one of 14 New Climate projects scheduled for Robert Redford’s film festival.
keywords: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power (Movie)

items.title: Fighting Climate Change, One Laundry Load at a Time
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: Experts in the study of fungi are playing a bigger role in improving laundry detergents and, by extension, leading efforts to cut energy use.

items.title: Review: ‘The Green Fog,’ a Salute to Hitchcock’s San Francisco
items.author: By Ben Kenigsberg
items.abstract: The documentary is a sort of fast-forward remake of “Vertigo,” built from clips of movies and TV shows shot in the city.

items.title: To Fight Climate Change, New York City Takes On Oil Companies
items.author: By William Neuman
items.abstract: The de Blasio administration is suing five major oil companies over climate change, and urging city pension funds to divest from fossil fuel firms.

items.title: A Greener, More Healthful Place to Work
items.author: By Richard Schiffman
items.abstract: Biophilic buildings aim not just to leave a minimal carbon footprint but also to promote the health of those who live and work there.

items.title: Battling Climate Change from the Back Seat of an S.U.V.
items.author: By Jim Dwyer
items.abstract: Mayor de Blasio declared himself a foe of global warming by filing suit against big oil companies, but his travel habits undermine his rhetoric.

items.title: The Three Simple Tonics That Sustain One of New York’s Busiest Chefs
items.author: By Priya Krishna
items.abstract: Daniela Soto-Innes, a co-owner of the acclaimed restaurants Cosme and Atla, shares a trio of recipes inspired by her Mexican grandmother’s natural remedies.

items.title: ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ and ‘Green Book’ Share Spotlight at the Golden Globes
items.author: By Brooks Barnes
items.abstract: Rami Malek and Glenn Close took best drama acting awards. Alfonso Cuarón won best director for “Roma.”

items.title: Climate Change, U.S. Shutdown, Michael Cohen: Your Friday Briefing
items.author: By Penn Bullock
items.abstract: Let us help you start your day.

items.title: ‘Green Book’ Writer Apologizes for Anti-Muslim Twitter Post From 2015
items.author: By Sopan Deb
items.abstract: Vallelonga apologized for agreeing with Donald J. Trump’s false claim that thousands of Muslims danced on rooftops in Jersey City after September 11.

items.title: Legalized Marijuana. A ‘Green New Deal.’ Cuomo’s 2019 Vision Tacks Left.
items.author: By Vivian Wang and Jesse McKinley
items.abstract: Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat re-elected in November, presented an aggressively progressive platform promising to make New York a leader among liberal states.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Your New Year’s Resolutions Count
items.author: By Tatiana Schlossberg and Tryggvi Adalbjornsson
items.abstract: Also this week, holiday fireworks in Iceland and beyond

items.title: Carlos Ghosn Was Aided in Flight From Japan by Former Green Beret
items.author: By Ben Dooley and David Yaffe-Bellany
items.abstract: More details about the former auto executive’s escape emerged. The Japanese news media said cameras showed him leaving his Tokyo home alone.

items.title: To Fight Climate Change, One City May Ban Heating Homes With Natural Gas
items.author: By Mike Baker
items.abstract: Seeking to do their part to avert climate change, dozens of cities are exploring ways to limit natural gas heating in new homes. One city may also require existing homeowners to make a switch.

items.title: Marine Labs on the Water’s Edge Are Threatened by Climate Change
items.author: By John Schwartz and Bryan Tarnowski
items.abstract: A marine lab built to withstand hurricanes faces a slower menace: climate change. Problems arising wherever science operates at the shifting border of soil and sea.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Help to Preserve Forests
items.author: By Jillian Mock, Nadja Popovich and John Schwartz
items.abstract: Also this week, wildfires in Australia

items.title: U.S. Disaster Costs Doubled in 2020, Reflecting Costs of Climate Change
items.author: By Christopher Flavelle
items.abstract: The $95 billion in damage came in a year marked by a record number of named Atlantic storms, as well as the largest wildfires recorded in California.

items.title: A Capitol Police officer dies from injuries sustained during the pro-Trump rampage.
items.author: By Mike Baker
items.abstract: Officer Brian D. Sicknick died Thursday night. Officials said he was “injured while physically engaging with protesters.”

items.title: Supreme Court Case Could Limit Future Lawsuits Against Fossil Fuel Industry
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: The court heard arguments on a technical legal question in a case that demands fossil fuel companies help pay for the costs of dealing with climate change.

items.title: Even for Bargain Hunters, Green Cars Make Sense
items.author: By Margaret Renkl
items.abstract: Electric cars are an even better value than I understood when I first bought one.

items.title: Climate Change Is Worsening. So the Weather Station Is Singing About It.
items.author: By Lindsay Zoladz
items.abstract: The 36-year-old Canadian musician Tamara Lindeman’s piercing new album, “Ignorance,” explores the emotional impacts of a global problem.

items.title: Bloomfield, N.J.: A Walkable Suburb With Plenty of Green Space
items.author: By Kathleen Lynn
items.abstract: Less than 20 miles from Midtown, the Essex County township appeals to those who want to move out of the city without leaving its conveniences behind.

items.title: Hochul Vows to Lift Economy, Lure Health Workers and Add a Transit Link
items.author: By Mihir Zaveri
items.abstract: The proposals, released as part of Ms. Hochul’s first State of the State address, reflected her priorities as she prepares to run for a full term as governor.
keywords: New York City Environmental Justice Alliance

items.title: New York Could Make History With a Fashion Sustainability Act
items.author: By Vanessa Friedman
items.abstract: The state would be the first to pass legislation setting broad sustainability regulations for the industry.

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.author: By Michael Kolomatsky
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: A Love of Trees or a Display of Power? The Odd Park of an Oligarch.
items.author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
items.abstract: A billionaire former prime minister says he has retired from Georgia’s fraught politics. His critics say he still wields considerable power. What’s beyond dispute: his obsession with trees.

items.title: Jeremiah Green, Drummer for Modest Mouse, Dies at 45
items.author: By Alex Traub
items.abstract: Mr. Green was a founder of the group, an indie band that rose to mainstream success. He was also one of its most enduring members.

items.title: On the Streets of Dakar, a Kaleidoscope of Style
items.author: By Simbarashe Cha
items.abstract: The capital of Senegal has become a fashion center. But photographing stylish people going about their day isn’t as easy as clicking a button.

items.title: Is a Dam in Rural Portugal a Key to Our Alternative Energy Future?
items.author: By Stanley Reed and Matilde Viegas
items.abstract: When the Portuguese electric power grid needs more electricity, a large multinational power company releases millions of gallons of water from a dammed reservoir.

items.title: Uber Drivers Say They Are Struggling: ‘This Is Not Sustainable’
items.author: By Winnie Hu and Ana Ley
items.abstract: Drivers’ hourly earnings have increased since 2018, but the company sued to block their raise last year and inflation has taken a toll.

items.title: Should an Oil Executive Oversee Climate Talks? The U.A.E. Thinks So.
items.author: By Euan Ward and Vivian Nereim
items.abstract: Sultan Al Jaber, who heads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, was chosen by the United Arab Emirates to head the upcoming COP28 summit, drawing criticism from green groups.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
